Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 02:26PM webu wrote: The cable guy just left and I finally have internet access again after 5 days. How did we ever survive before the internet? Anyway, I had my first TCH tx last Friday. I haven't felt too sick, but I haven't felt too great either. The nausea didn't get too bad but the constipation, cramping and diarrhea have been a problem. My stomach is so bloated all I can wear are my husband's sweatpants. I know chemo can cause weight gain, but I didn't think it would be so immediate.  Also, I'm getting mouth sores even though I've been rinsing with the Biotene. I read about the liquid maalox/liquid benadryl mix, but when I went to the store to pick up the liquid benadryl, I found out it had been recalled, and there were no generic versions on the shelf. Does anyone know of any alternatives? I ordered a wig on Saturday. I also got my hair cut really short. It is not very flattering, so I don't think I'll mind so much when it falls out. It sounds like some of you are having a really difficult time, and my heart goes out to you. Sometimes I think we are getting the  the message from the media that we are supposed to be pink ribbon warriors fighting with all our might against the enemy cancer, and some of us feel guilty for having  days where we feel sick and scared and angry instead of brave and positive. Does anyone else feel like this?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2011 02:23PM webu wrote: navywife - my heart goes out to you, nobody should have to spend their 30th birthday being treated for cancer. I understand your fears but MaryMeg is right in saying you should focus on the odds. You have an excellent chance of recovery. lorenar -Good for you being able to walk the dog. My poor dog hasn't had a good walk in weeks. I feel so guilty when she stands by the front door looking hopeful, but I just haven't been able to face the freezing cold and the snow and the ice.  aimeemac and marymeg - OMG those Nainamo bars look good! JulieH - I hope you called the doctor today. That sounds like something you should definitely get checked out. amelia2 - my hair will start going any day now, and the waiting is hard. I can imagine it will be a relief when I finally get it all shaved off. bdavis - You are right to try to get the BRCA test because the results can help you determine your future course of treatment. Also, if the results are negative, it can give you some peace of mind.   Today I finally feel like myself again. The mouth sores are all gone and I can eat again and I don't have that chemical taste anymore. This is day 13 and my next chemo is a week from Friday. I'm hoping I'm not going to be sick for two out of every three week cycle. My mail just came and I received my free Gaila Fund hat/scarf whatever is is. It's really nice. I recommend that any of you who haven't yet ordered one go to their website. These normally cost $75 and are very good quality. I also got a couple of hats from Headcovers.com, and they are really cute.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 23, 2011 04:34PM webu wrote: proudmom_wife - I'm still having a lot of trouble with the mouth sores. I have heard that tumeric can cure a lot of things. How much did you use in your tea? Why did your onc want you to stop two days before treatment? On the plus side, I'm one of the lucky ones who had no pain from the neulasta shot.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 30, 2011 09:59AM webu wrote: Today my hair is coming out in in bunches. I had to pull out the vacuum cleaner because it was making such a mess, and now I'm wearing a scarf to contain it all. This is upsetting me more than I thought it would. Maybe it's because now I am visibly a cancer patient. Julie it was good to hear you didn't feel too self-conscious when you went out. I'm sure I'll get over this. Moe - I hope you get lots of rest today and feel better fast  I hope everyone is having a good weekend. Wendi
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 11:41AM webu wrote: Hi everyone. We were literally snowed in this morning. There were 4 foot snowdrifts outside all our doors. Fortunately we have a great plow service and they showed up an hour ago to plow the driveway, so we can at least get out through the garage. Unfortunately most of the streets around here aren't plowed, so we can't go anywhere, but I was at least able to let the dog out to do her business. Poor girl was about to explode. Annie, SusanLynn, and Julie - I'm glad to hear that so far your 2nd tx SEs haven't been too bad. That is reassuring because mine is in two days. I hope you all continue to feel good. Julie - You look great in your new picture! I'm not quite brave enough yet to take a picture of my bald head, but here I am in one of my new scarves.  ProudMom_Wife - Good luck today with your 3rd tx. I agree with you that it is kind of nice not to have to spend time blow-drying my hair UTMom2014 - Your wig is very cute. I'm having trouble with mine. It looked good in the wigshop when they styled it for me, but I can't get it to look right. I think I need to take it to my stylist. Lorenar - Glad to hear you are feeling a little better. bdavis - I got my buzz cut about 4 days after shedding started. I still had most of my hair left but my scalp was hurting a lot. It felt better as soon as the hair buzzed.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2011 05:56PM webu wrote: Welcome to the club, golfergrandma. I, too, am very sorry to hear you are going through this a second time. My onc said a few glasses of wine a week, shouldn't be a problem. Right now I can still drink white wine, but for some reason red wine just doesn't taste right. Julie - I got my scarf from abonitascarf.com. They don't have a very big selection, but what they do have is cute and not terribly expensive compared to some of the other site. I also "saw stars" for a few days during the first week after tx. It happened whenever I turned my head to the side. It never got too bad, though, and it went away after a few days, so I never mentioned it to my onc. UTMom - I didn't get the neulasta shot right after my first tx because my onc wanted to wait to see if I needed it. I ended up feeling exhausted and getting mouth sores, and it turned out my WBC went down to 1. I got the neulasta shot a week after tx, and within a few days I felt much better. Hey, I just realized another good thing about being bald; no hat-head
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 9, 2011 05:25PM webu wrote: Sherry - I'm so glad to hear your daughter responded positively. We just arranged for a home pass for my daughter for late next week. I'm nervous but really excited. She has not been home for a little over a year now. 1Miclon - I'm so sorry you lost your husband and now you have to go through this. Life is just too unfair, sometimes. You will find this is a great place for support. kadorazio - I think  a lot of us found we were able to stay upbeat at first but eventually it all gets to us and we have days where we don't think we can get through all of this. I think that is perfectly normal. I know one thing that helps me is to come on these boards to rant and talk to others going through the same things. Just do whatever you need to take care of yourself right now I have started using one of those dog hair remover rollers (with the sticky tape) on my head everyday. It removes all of the loose prickly hairs and I don't feel itchy. What I hate is that I have these sideburns that are not going anywhere while the rest of my hair is almost gone. They stick out of the wig and other headcoverings, and it is not a great look. I tried shaving them but I get 5:00 shadow (more like 2:00 shadow) I'm wondering if I should get them waxed. jcoutee, I know what you mean about this weather. I feel trapped in the house by the snow and ice and cold. Today I went to the grocery store and I wore a heavy winter hat because it is 8 degrees out, but after 15 minutes at the store I was so hot I thought I would faint, and I wanted more than anything to tear that hat off. I cheered myself up by making a big pot of chicken soup and baking some cinnamon scones. My house smells sooo good now.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 01:56PM webu wrote: TCH starting 1/14/1, cycle 2 of 6 2/4/11, weekly H   I decided to put my treatment plan below in my signature because I will never remember to put the info every time. Speaking of not remembering, anyone else suffering from the dreaded chemo-brain?  Twice this week I  have taken pots off the stove and not realized for at least an hour that the flame was still on. Worse, last night I was supposed to go to a program on Living with Cancer at the cancer center. I had been looking forward to it because it covered many interesting topics, including coping with chemo-brain.  I even got a reminder call in the morning. Somehow, I got busy with other stuff and just totally forgot about it until this morning. Today I was working, doing some bookkeeping, and I enter 15 deposits as debits before I realized what I was doing. This is very upsetting! I thought before that people were exaggerating about chemo-brain; that it was kind of like the absent-mindedness  we got when we were pregnant. This is much worse!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 08:41AM webu wrote: AimeeMac - I know just what you mean about that "trying to get everything done" feeling. Last time I was up late the night before trying to get work done and I was getting upset with myself that I couldn't do it all, with the result that I went to tx already exhausted and stressed out. Next time I swear I am going to be easier on myself. The world is not going to end if I let a few things slide.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 15, 2011 04:39PM webu wrote: tfinn99 - I'm sorry you are having such a rough time. I hope you feel better soon. Kym61 - I don't even know what to say. I'm so sorry to hear about your biopsy results. I can't really help you with deciding about options because I only needed a lumpectomy, but I'm sure other people will have good advice. Let us know how everything goes. DancingMom -  Don't be hard on yourself. When my two kids were smaller, I could never keep up with the house, and I didn't have breast cancer at the time. You can only do so much.

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2011 02:46PM webu wrote: Hi everyone. I'm ready to join the club.  I start chemo this Friday the 14th. I'm doing TCH x 6. I got a tour of the infusion room this morning; it was actually quite lively back there. I'll be really glad to get this first one done with. It is so helpful to hear what everyone is going through day by day. It definitely cuts down on the anxiety.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2011 02:34PM webu wrote: Welcome Jane and Sciencegirl and good luck to both of you. sicst12 - What a great idea!  I start tomorrow on TCH x6.  I went to Sams Club today and loaded up on Miralex, Aleve, imodium, prevacid, Claritin and hemorroid (sp?) wipes. I must have looked like the biggest hypochondriac in the world, but I want to be ready for anything.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2011 06:28PM webu wrote: I went for my weekly herceptin today (I had my first taxotere/ carboplatene/herceptin a week ago). My onc didn't give me a neulasta shot last week because he likes to wait to see if there is a problem first, but today my wbc was only 1.1, so I got the shot. My mouth sores were so bad today it is hard to swallow anything, and I also have a pimply rash all over my body, which the doc says is probably a reaction to the steroids. I left the office with a prescription for leviquin,  an antiviral med and a topical cream for the rash. I'm definitely going to need a bigger medicine cabinet.  Also, the nurse was unable to draw blood from my port today. Apparently, they sometimes get clogged and she had to put something in that cleaned it out but took an hour and a half to do so. In the meantime, they stuck an IV in my hand for the herceptin.  JulieH - The onc said that people who get a lot of cold sores tend to have more problems with mouth sores when getting chemo, so hopefully the antiviral will help. I also have the magic mouthwash and biotene rinse. I can't stand gargling with salt water either. Thanks for the suggestion of the biotene gel. I know overnight is when my mouth really gets dried out. AImeeMac - Your husband is a darling! Science Girl - Sorry about the pain and low WBC. I hope you got a good nap today.  UTMom2014 - I'm so sorry you had to spend all that time in the hospital.  cblue17 -  Impacted bowels sounds really unpleasant. I'm sure they told you to start taking something like Miralax and a stool softener before the next tx. I know that even though I did that, I couldn't go until the 4th day and I felt like I would explode.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 24, 2011 03:56PM webu wrote: I cut my hair very short last week before chemo. When I wake up in the morning I have that Annette Benning at the Golden Globes look. I'm almost happy about shaving it off. I noticed my head has been very itchy today. Is that the first sign it is going to fall out? I'm on day 11 so I guess it will be soon. MaryMeg - You are so funny with the tape patterns. Your friends sound great.  ProudMom_wife - Thanks for the recipe. I'll ask my onc about the tumeric.

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 12:36PM webu wrote: Wow, MaryMeg and Aimeemac. You both express yourself so beautifully, and what you have to say really resonates. I was telling my aunt (a cancer survivor)  yesterday that I felt guilty because I haven't been going to the office, and she said "Your job right now is to get better and that is a full time job. If some days that job is all can can do, you should still pat yourself on the back for a job will done" . Welcome lorenar and jcoutee. Sorry you have to join us, but you will find so much information and support on these boards.  I have notice the vision thing too. At first I kept trying to clean my glasses, thinking they were dirty. I don't remember reading about this SE. I sure hope it is temporary.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 1, 2011 07:32AM webu wrote: Hi everyone. I got my hair buzzed yesterday. At first I didn't want to look in the mirror, but I'm getting used to it. I purchased  a good synthetic, monofiliment wig. I  think it is going to take some time to get used to it. have a feeling I am only going to wear it to the office and if I am going out somewhere nice. Has anyone found a good hat to sleep in? I get cold at night, but the sleep cap I ordered had elastic around the rim that made it uncomfortable and I took it off in the middle of the night. My poor DH had to wake up to the lovely site of me bald and snoring. Oh well, I see him bald and snoring all the time. I am grateful right now that the hair is all I have to worry about. Otherwise I am feeling good and my energy level is back to what is was pre-treatment. I feel for all of you who are having a hard time.  Marymeg - Your posts are so entertaining! Are you a professional writer? I'm sorry you have not been feeling well, and good luck on looking "more languid and Garbo"  I just found out our office will be closed tomorrow due to the blizzard coming our way. Yeah, snow day!!!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 09:43AM webu wrote: Amy and sicst12 - You WILL get through this. Lately when I'm not feeling good I tell myself that it is because right now my body is a battlefield.  The good guy chemo is fighting the bad cancer.   I think about each treatment as providing more ammo for the good guys. This helps me to not dread the next treatment so much. I have the sore tongue thing too. I wonder what causes that?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 02:35PM webu wrote: Anniemomofthree - I'm glad you asked for disability. It must be a relief to have one less thing to deal with. I'm doing the Taxotere like you and Sciencegirl. It's interesting that all three of us are having vision issues... SSIrish - Welcome from a fellow Chicago- area girl. I love the Rhoda Morgenstern comment. I had forgotten about her and her head scarves. I'm with you on hibernating for the next few month. Some days I don't even want to go outside to get the mail. Sorry you had such a lousy birthday. I hope your SEs aren't too bad this time either. baf4292 - I looked through that book at the bookstore, and it did look good. I would also recommend "Cancer is a B*tch" by Gail Konop Baker, a memoir of her year with breast cancer.  jcoutee - I know what you mean about being obsessed with your hair. I can't stop running my hands through mine to see if any comes out yet. So far, none, but I'm only on day 12... MaryMeg - LOL at your line about your children wanting to replace you with a less unreasonable mother. I'm sure my kids have wished that many times. I didn't get the neulasta shot after my first tx, but my onc wanted me to come back after 5 days and get a CBC. My wbc went down very low so I ended up getting the shot that day. No SEs, though AimeMac - Good luck with your second cycle tomorrow.   Question of the day:  What is a Nanaimo bar ?
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2011 02:29PM webu wrote: Welcome EmilyinOntario and tfinn99. Sorry you have to go through this but glad you are here to keep the rest of us company. Tidenott - I meant to tell you yesterday I am so sorry to hear you lost your daughter. I know that nobody who has not gone through that can even imagine what it must be like, but my heart goes out to you. I think yesterday's tx hit me faster than the first one. I have been exhausted, fuzzy-brained and queasy all day today. I went to get my neulasta shot this morning (would you believe my insurance company won't cover it unless it is done in a doctor's office) and then I spent the afternoon snoozing in a chair.I have a ton of work to do and I really hoped I would have a couple of days to do it before I felt sick again. bdavis- My hair was buzzed to about half an inch. I have been shampooing and conditioning it and it doesn't itch. I did notice today that a lot has fallen out and I have several big bald spots
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 23, 2011 03:13PM webu wrote: I haven't been on for several days so I have a lot of catching up to do. I've been feeling good, except for runny nose and eyes. I just got back from driving my daughter from Chicago back to her school in Omaha because she missed her flight yesterday (long story). I usually don't mind driving long distances but was a little worried I might get too tired this time; however, I was fine. I did have an episode of chemo brain, though. Last night I checked into my hotel and then went out for dinner with DD. After I dropped her at her place, I went back to the hotel. I could not get the door to my room open, even though I knew I had the right room number because I had written it down. I went to the front desk and told the clerk that my keycard was not working.  She looked at me kind of funny and told me it was because this was the Holiday Inn and my keycard was for the Candlewood Suites next door.  I was one very red-faced bald lady! In my defense though, the two hotels did have very similar interiors. MaryMeg, I thought about you when I saw the news about the earthquake. I'm very glad to hear you and your family are okay. Regarding the carboplatin, I'm on TCH and for what it's worth, though my first treatment was a little rough, after the second I just had a few days of nausea and have been fine ever since. My third tx is the day after tomorrow, so I hope it will be as easy. Amelia - I agree with everyone else who is telling you to go to Hawaii, especially if your oncologists approve it. I can't think of a more relaxing place.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2011 04:47PM webu wrote: ProudMom_Wife - Good for you! I was just reading through the printouts on SEs my infusion center gave me, and while it doesn't mention Taxotere as causing any vision problems, it does say this: "In rare cases, carboplatin can cause loss of vision, especially of light and colors. This symptom usually gets better within a few weeks of stopping the drug"  Yikes!
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 28, 2011 03:12PM webu wrote: islandmom - hope your SEs are mild this time. 4 to 5 visits a week to the gym is fantastic. I still haven't made it once since my partial mx, and I'm starting to feel really flabby. jcoutee - It's good to hear you are feeling well after your 4th Taxol. I am 14 days out from my first TCH and I'm sitting here waiting for my hair to fall out, too. I just want to get it over with already. Tundra - How frustrating to have your tx postponed! When my wbc was really low last week I know I felt kind of depressed and exhausted, too. As soon as I had the neulasta shot I felt much better. Anniemomofthree - I am also on TCH and my onc said something about lowering the next dose because of the SEs I had with the first. He says it is normal to adjust the dose after the first treatment. ck-mama - It sounds horrible getting stuck like that in the storm after you have just had surgery. You must be in pretty good shape to be able to push the car and walk all that way. My DH and I lived in Baltimore for a couple years when we were first married, and being from Chicago, we were amazed at how just a couple of inches of snow could shut down the city, because they didn't have the equipment to salt the roads or clear the snow. I can't even imagine how it is there with these mega-snows that have been hitting the area for the last few years.  Sciencegirl - I'm with you on feeling like I'm on a weight roller coaster. I think it has to do with the constipation,too. My weight has been varying by as much as five pounds from day to day. I had my third Herceptin infusion today. I didn't have any problems and I'm feeling pretty good right now.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 09:28AM webu wrote: Annie -I had the same problem with losing what I wrote when I went back a page. The trick is to highlight and save your text to the clipboard (control + C) before you go back, then paste it (Control + V) into the text box when you are ready to start typing again. At least that is what I have been doing. Someone else may know of a better way. Today my hair started falling out. I woke up and there was a bunch of hair on my pillow. So far it is just coming off the top of my head, so I have a small bald spot. Even though I knew this was coming (it is day 15) there is a difference between knowing it is going to happen and actually seeing it happen. I'm a little freaked out right now. We are going out for dinner with friends tonight, and I'm wondering if I will have to wear a hat or scarf.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 03:52PM webu wrote: Julie - Your idea to use notepad is much better than mine. Glad to hear shaving your head wasn't traumatic. I'm going to go to my wig place on Monday and have it done.   MaryMeg - I'm sitting here in the cold, snowy, dark midwest picturing you enjoying a beautiful, warm, sunny summer day. If you are not careful, we are all going to show up at your door.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2011 03:09PM webu wrote: Happy Birthday, MaryMeg!  I, too, have found some positives in this experience. I was very touched by the way my family and friends have rallied around me. I've talked to my brothers more in the last few months than we talked in the last 10 years. My son calls me from college every few days to check on me and tell me he loves me, which I probably hadn't heard from him since he was 5.  The biggest positive, though, has been with my daughter. Two years ago, at the age of 16, she became Every Parent's Nightmare. Drugs, drinking, staying out all night, shop-lifting, ditching classes. We went though a year of hell with her, and when it got to the point where we discovered she could no longer get through the day without smoking weed, that she smoked it before school, during school, after school. She also had a new boyfriend who turned out to be a heroin addict and drug dealer.   We realized last January that we had to send her away, first to a wilderness program and then to a therapeutic boarding school. For the first 10 months she was angry and very hostile to us when we visited. She ran away once when I was supposed to meet her at the airport and take her to her new school. That was the longest two days of my life until the police found her. She kept threatening she would walk out when she turned 18, which was last October. We ended up transfering her to a residential treatment center in in a state  where the age of majority is 19. When we went to visit her there on her birthday, she screamed at us that she hated us and was never going to have anything to do with us again. She refused to talk to us on the phone. When I was diagnosed in November I wanted to visit the school to tell her, but her therapist recommended against it. She was afraid for me because she didn't know how DD would react and it might be nasty. I ended up telling her in a letter which her therapist read with her. That night DD called me crying and told me she loved me and was so sorry for everything she put me through. She blamed herself for my cancer and promised she was going to really start working hard to show she still wanted to be part of the family. Since that day there has been a remarkable turnaround in her behavior. We talk almost every day, and I had a great visit with her right before I started treatment. She got her GED and is now taking community college courses online. Her therapist says she really is a new person. It looks like she will be coming home in the spring, and I am looking forward to having her here. I don't know what would have happened if i hadn't gotten cancer. Maybe she would have turned around eventually, but it's hard to say.  Her best friend started using heroin after we sent DD away, and I just found out she is now missing and thought to be living on the streets somewhere. That so easily could have been my daughter. Life can take strange turns, sometimes, so if going though breast cancer is going to bring me my daughter back, so be it.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2011 11:11AM webu wrote: I am writing this from the infusion center where I am getting my 2nd TCH. I wrote a whole long post but I accidently erased it when the benedryl started to take effect. So far, so good. Sherry -While I agree with the others that your daughter should know about your cancer, you also have to protect yourself. I think my DDs therapist had the right idea when she suggested the letter. We really had no idea how DD would react. In my worst imaginings I pictured her saying she hoped I would die. I wrote her a very short, simple letter, telling her I had breast cancer, that the prognosis was good and that I really hoped she would be able to give me her love and support. Fortunately, she came around, and hopefully your daughter will, too, but you have to be prepared for the worst. That is why a letter or having a close family member tell her are both good options while avoiding a confrontation that you just don't need right now. I really pray it goes well for you. Tidenott - Love the Jimmy Buffet quote! I hope everyone else is doing well today. Wendi
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Feb 8, 2011 08:35AM webu wrote: Beckie, your picture with your family makes me feel good just looking at it. You do bald beautfully! Like several of you, I felt worse after my 2nd treatment Friday. The nausea was pretty bad and I pretty much slept the whole weekend. The good news is that today I am starting to feel much better. Last time the SEs didn't start until the 3rd day and lasted almost two weeks. Last time, though, I didn't get the Neulasta shot until a week later, when my wbc had already plunged and I'd developed mouth sores. Hopefully, this time I will avoid all that. {{{Hugs}}} to all of you who are having a rough time right now. It does help that we are all going through this together.  I am wearing my wig right now and trying to get used to it, but scarves are much more comfortable. I have a bumpy head that does not look good bald. I swear my dog keeps doing double-takes when she sees me because my head looks different all the time.
Posts.Title: Starting Chemo in January '11 JulieH leftfootforward

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2011 05:44PM webu wrote: huntreiter - I know just how you feel. In fact, this very topic came up recently at a cancer support group I just joined. As women, our first instinct is to try to make our family and friends feel better, even if it means downplaying our own distress and putting on a pretend happy face. This can get very exhausting, though. Even if the prognosis is good, we are still facing a frightening disease and going through difficult treatments with many scary side effects. You are definitely entitled to these feelings. That is why support groups and forums like these are so important; they let us rant and cry among people who understand just what we are going through.
Posts.Title: Depression Over Good Prognosis? huntreiter3 Momine

Posts.Content: webu wrote: Hi everybody. I was recently diagnosed and I am scheduled for a lumpectomy this coming Monday. I had an abdominal CT scan last week which showed an enlarged gallbladder. I then had an MRI of the abdomen which shows that the gallbladder is grossly distended and that there is a large stone blocking drainage. My BS (who only does breasts) sent me to a general surgeon who thinks the gall bladder should come out. She said it is clearly palpable and has probably been slowly getting larger for a while now.  I have had problems with bloating, constipation and indigestion for several years. I was always told it was "irritable bowel syndrome" and there was nothing much I could do about it except try relaxation exercises. My internist never mentioned gallbladder disease, even though it always hurt when she poked that area. I guess I should have been a little more assertive before, because this is the last thing I want to deal with right now. The two surgeons have spoken and agreed that after the one completes the breast surgery on Monday, the other one will come in and remove the gallbladder. She is pretty sure she can do this laparoscopically, but she says there is always the chance she won't be able to get all of it and will have to cut me open. The surgeons agree that I'm better off having one surgery then having to come back a week or two later to take care of the gallbladder. They say the gallbladder definitely has to come out before I start chemo. I wish I had more time to decide. On the one hand, I hate the thought of going through 2 separate surgeries within a few weeks; on the other hand I'm guessing that having both procedures plus the lymph node biopsy at the same time is going to be hard on my body and will mean a more difficult recovery. I can't believe this is all happening.  Lumpectomy 12/6/11; TCH x 6, weekly Herceptin during chemo and then every three weeks for a total of twelve months - start date 1/14/11 - chemo will be followed by rads Dx 11/12/2010, IDC, 2cm, Stage II, Grade 3, 0/5 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Surgery Monday, now gallbladder problem too webu webu

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2010 09:03AM webu wrote: Thanks Lowrider and Lisa. I feel better about it now.
Posts.Title: Surgery Monday, now gallbladder problem too webu webu

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2011 03:09PM webu wrote: I've asked three oncs about LVI because it was on my lab report, too, and they all said it wasn't something to worry about (easy for them to say). They all said  that it wouldn't make any difference to my treatment if it was present or not; that the important factors in deciding on treatment were tumor grade and my HER+ status. Once did say he would prefer not to see LVI present, but by itself it is not an indication that the cancer is more likely to spread.
Posts.Title: Vascular Invasion... WHAT does that REALLY mean? Nicole112 barbe1958
